notification_status.description: The current notification status for this abandonded order, which can be one of `not_sent`, `scheduled`, or `sent`.

status.description: The current status of this abandonded order, which can be one of `not_notified`, `notified`, or `recovered`.

latest_order.description: This customer's most recent order with `total_amount > 0`.

currency.description: The default currency for this account. This will be used as the default value for `Price`, `Order`, and other objects that have the `currency` attribute.

name.description: The full name, business name, or other short descriptor for this account.

url.description: The URL of this account's store. This will be used as the fallback `return_url` when one is not set on other objects (i.e. orders, customer links, etc.).

owner.description: The associated user that owns this account.

city.description: City, district, suburb, town, or village.

line_1.description: Address line 1 (e.g., street, PO Box, or company name).

line_2.description: Address line 2 (e.g., apartment, suite, unit, or building).

name.description: The full name or business name for this address. (If empty, this will fallback to the customer's name.)

amount.description: The amount of the transaction. A negative value is a credit for the customer’s balance, and a positive value is a debit to the customer’s balance.

currency.description: Three-letter ISO currency code, in lowercase. This must match the customer's currency.

ending_customer_balance_amount.description: The customer’s `balance` after the transaction was applied.

transaction_type.description: One of either `adjustment`, `applied_to_invoice`, `invoice_below_currency_minimum`, or `invoice_credit`. Balance transactions created through the API are always `adjustment` transactions.

email.description: The email address that will be shown to customers for support, on invoices, etc.

inherit_account_address.description: If set to `true` the account's legal business address will be used instead of the brand's address.

phone.description: The phone number that will be shown to customers for support, on invoices, etc.

website.description: The website that will be shown to customers for support, on invoices, etc.

logo_upload_id.description: The upload UUID that you want to attach to this brand. This will replace the existing logo, if one exists. If `purge_logo` is also set to `true` the new logo will not be attached.

purge_logo.description: If set to `true` the brand logo will be removed.

logo_url.description: The URL of the brand logo.

brand.description: The brand of the card, which can be `amex`, `diners`, `discover`, `jcb`, `mastercard`, `unionpay`, `visa`, or `unknown`.

exp_month.description: Two-digit number representing the card’s expiration month.

exp_year.description: Four-digit number representing the card’s expiration year.

last4.description: The last four digits of the card.

wallet_type.description: If this card is part of a card wallet, this will be set to the type of wallet. The current types are `amex_express_checkout`, `apple_pay`, `google_pay`, `masterpass`, `samsung_pay`, or `visa_checkout`.

amount.description: The amount in cents that was charged, represented as a whole integer. For example `9900` is equivalent to `$99`.

currency.description: Three-letter ISO currency code, in lowercase.

external_charge_id.description: The external processor ID representing this charge.

fully_refunded.description: Whether or not this charge has been refunded completely.

live_mode.description: Set to `true` if this charge is in live mode, and set to `false` if it is in test mode.

refunded_amount.description: Amount in cents refunded (can be less than the amount attribute on the charge if a partial refund was issued).

status.description: The current status of this charge, which can be one of `pending`, `succeeded`, or `failed`.

amount_off.description: Amount (in the `currency` specified) that will be taken off the subtotal of any order.

currency.description: If `amount_off` has been set, the three-letter ISO code for the currency of the amount to take off.

duration.description: One of `forever`, `once`, and `repeating`. Describes how long a discount with this coupon will be applied. (The `repeating` and `forever` values only apply to subscriptions.)

duration_in_months.description: If `duration` is `repeating`, the number of months the coupon applies. Null if coupon `duration` is `forever` or `once`.

max_redemptions.description: Maximum number of times this coupon can be redeemed, in total, across all customers, before it is no longer valid.

name.description: Name of the coupon displayed to customers.

percent_off.description: Percent that will be taken off the subtotal of any order. For example, a coupon with percent_off of 50 will make a $100 invoice $50 instead.

redeem_by.description: Date after which the coupon can no longer be redeemed.

expired.description: Taking into account the above properties, whether this coupon can still be applied to a order.

times_redeemed.description: Number of times this coupon has been applied to a order and/or subscription.

billing_matches_shipping.description: If set to `true` the shipping address will be used for the billing address.

name.description: The customer’s full name or business name.

unsubscribed.description: Set to `true` if this customer has unsubscribed from from opt-in emails (i.e. abandoned cart emails).

billing_address.description: The billing address for the customer.

shipping_address.description: The shipping address for the customer.

balance_amount.description: Current balance, if any, being stored on the customer. If negative, the customer has credit to apply to their next invoice. If positive, the customer has an amount owed that will be added to their next invoice. The balance does not refer to any unpaid invoices; it solely takes into account amounts that have yet to be succesfully applied to any invoice. This balance is only taken into account as invoices are finalized.

billing_address.description: The billing address for the customer.

currency.description: Three-letter ISO code for the currency this customer's balance is in, and the currency that can be used for subscriptions.

shipping_address.description: The shipping address for the customer.

email.description: The email used to lookup the customer.

return_url.description: The URL that the customer should be directed to when the click the link from their email. The return URL will have a `?customer_link_id=` parameter added to it.

expired.description: Whether or not this customer link is valid.

first_used_at.description: Date when the customer link was first used.

abandoned_orders_enabled.description: If set to `true` abandonded order reminder emails will be sent to customers.

dunning_enabled.description: If set to `true` subscription dunning emails will be sent to customers.

from_name.description: The from name to use when sending emails to customers.

locale.description: The language that will be used for all customer notifications. Current available locales are `de`, `en`, `es`, and `fr`.

reply_to_email.description: The reply-to email address to use when sending emails to customers.

promotion_code.description: The customer-facing code that will be used to lookup the promotion.

created_at.description: Time at which the object was created. Measured in seconds since the Unix epoch.

type.description: Description of the event (e.g., subscription.updated or charge.updated).

currency.description: Three-letter ISO currency code, in lowercase. If not set, this value will fallback to the default `Account` currency.

live_mode.description: Set to `true` if this invoice is in live mode, and set to `false` if it is in test mode.

period_end_at.description: End of the usage period during which invoice items were added to this invoice. This will be `null` when the invoice is for a subscription that has a price with `recurring_interval=never`.

period_start_at.description: Start of the usage period during which invoice items were added to this invoice.

billing_address.description: The billing address for this invoice.

discount.description: The parameters of the discount to be applied to this invoice.

invoice_items.description: A list of this invoice's invoice items.

shipping_address.description: The shipping address for this invoice.

tax_identifier.description: The tax identifier to set for this invoice.

amount_due.description: Total amount due after all adjustments (i.e. trials, credits, proration).

applied_balance_amount.description: The customer balance amount that was applied to this invoice.

discount_amount.description: Total discount amount of all invoice items.

invoice_items.description: A list of associated invoice items.

next_payment_retry_at.description: The time at which payment will be automatically retried.

number.description: A unique, identifying string that is used to reference this invoice.

payment_retry_count.description: Number of payment retries made for this invoice, from the perspective of the payment retry schedule. Only automatic retries increment the count. In other words, manual payment attempts do not impact the count.

payment_intent.description: The associated payment intent. (This will only be set once the invoice has been finalized.)

processor_data.description: All of the additional data necessary to capture payment with each processor.

stripe.description: All of the additional data necessary to capture payment with Stripe.

publishable_key.description: The publishable key to be used when instantiating StripeJS. For example, you will instantiate like this `Stripe(publishable_key);`.

proration_amount.description: Total amount to be prorated from this invoice which has been carried over from the subscription's previous invoice.

purchases.description: The associated purchases. (Only relevant for invoice items associated with one-time products.)

renewal.description: Whether or not this invoice has been generated automatically for a subscription renewal.

status.description: The current status of this invoice, which can be one of `draft`, `finalized`, `paid`, `payment_intent_canceled`, or `payment_failed`.

subtotal_amount.description: Total of all invoice items before discounts or taxes are applied.

tax_amount.description: Total tax amount of all invoice items.

tax_calculation_status.description: The status of tax calculations for this invoice. One of `disabled`, `shipping_address_required`, `shipping_address_country_required`, `shipping_address_state_required`, `shipping_address_postal_code_required`, `tax_registration_not_found`, `estimated`, or `calculated`.

tax_label.description: The type of tax that is applied to this order. For example, in the EU this value will be `VAT` and in the US this value will be `Tax`.

total_amount.description: Total of all invoice items after discounts and taxes are applied.

trial_amount.description: Total of all invoice items that have `trial` set to `true`.

quantity.description: The quantity of products being purchased.

subtotal_amount.description: Total before any discounts or taxes are applied.

total_amount.description: Total after discounts and taxes are applied.

trial.description: Set to `true` if this invoice item represents a subscription that is currently trialing.

ad_hoc_amount.description: The amount to use for this line item when the associated price is `ad_hoc=true`.

quantity.description: The quantity of products being purchased.

subtotal_amount.description: Total before any discounts or taxes are applied.

total_amount.description: Total after discounts and taxes are applied.

trial.description: Set to `true` if this line item is for a price that has a default trial.

currency.description: Three-letter ISO currency code, in lowercase. If not set, this value will fallback to the default `Account` currency.

group_key.description: A key used to retrieve groups of orders dynamically from a static string.

live_mode.description: Set to `true` if this order is in live mode, and set to `false` if it is in test mode.

return_url.description: The URL that the customer should be directed to from abandoned cart emails. The return URL will have a `?order_id=` parameter added to it.

billing_address.description: The billing address for this order.

discount.description: The parameters of the discount to be applied to this order.

line_items.description: A list of this order's line items.

refresh_price_versions.description: When set to true the prices that are associated with each line item will be refreshed to reference the most recent version. (This should be used if you are receiving an error when trying to finalize a order that is referencing old price versions.)

shipping_address.description: The shipping address for this order.

tax_identifier.description: The tax identifier to set for this order.

amount_due.description: Total amount due after all adjustments (i.e. trials).

customer.description: The associated customer. (This will only be set once the order has been finalized.)

discount_amount.description: Total discount amount of all line items.

line_items.description: A list of associated line items.

number.description: A unique, identifying string that is used to reference this order.

payment_intent.description: The associated payment intent. (This will only be set once the order has been finalized.)

processor_data.description: All of the additional data necessary to capture payment with each processor.

stripe.description: All of the additional data necessary to capture payment with Stripe.

publishable_key.description: The publishable key to be used when instantiating StripeJS. For example, you will instantiate like this `Stripe(publishable_key);`.

purchases.description: The associated purchases. (Only relevant for line items associated with one-time products.)

status.description: The current status of this order, which can be one of `draft`, `finalized`, `paid`, `payment_intent_canceled`, or `payment_failed`.

subtotal_amount.description: Total of all line items before discounts or taxes are applied.

tax_amount.description: Total tax amount of all line items.

tax_calculation_status.description: The status of tax calculations for this order. One of `disabled`, `shipping_address_required`, `shipping_address_country_required`, `shipping_address_state_required`, `shipping_address_postal_code_required`, `tax_registration_not_found`, `estimated`, or `calculated`.

tax_label.description: The type of tax that is applied to this order. For example, in the EU this value will be `VAT` and in the US this value will be `Tax`.

total_amount.description: Total of all line items after discounts and taxes are applied.

trial_amount.description: Total of all invoice items that have `trial` set to `true`.

live_mode.description: Set to `true` if this order is in live mode, and set to `false` if it is in test mode.

processor_type.description: The processor being used for this order. The only allowed processor right now is `stripe`.

external_intent_id.description: The external ID necessary to capture payment through this processor. For example, if processing through Stripe, the `external_intent_id` will be set to the `Stripe::PaymentIntent` ID.

processor_data.description: All of the additional data necessary to capture payment with each processor.

stripe.description: All of the additional data necessary to capture payment with Stripe.

client_secret.description: The client secret for this Stripe intent.

payment_method_id.description: The Stripe payment method ID associated with this intent.

publishable_key.description: The publishable key to be used when instantiating StripeJS. For example, you will instantiate like this `Stripe(publishable_key);`.

type.description: The type of Stripe intent – can be one of `payment` or `setup`. This will determine whether you use the StripeJS `confirmCardPayment` or `confirmCardSetup` function.

status.description: The status of this payment intent, one of `pending`, `canceled`, or `succeeded`.

external_payment_method_id.description: The external processor ID representing this payment method.

live_mode.description: Set to `true` if this charge is in live mode, and set to `false` if it is in test mode.

processor_type.description: The specific type of processor. The only allowed processor right now is `stripe`.

type.description: The type of payment method. The only available type right now is `card`.

ad_hoc.description: Whether or not this price accepts ad hoc amounts – also known as custom or user-defined amounts.

ad_hoc_max_amount.description: The maximum ad hoc amount in cents to be allowed, represented as a whole integer. For example `9900` is equivalent to `$99`.

ad_hoc_min_amount.description: The minimum ad hoc amount in cents to be allowed, represented as a whole integer. For example `9900` is equivalent to `$99`. If left blank, this will be interpreted as `0`.

amount.description: The amount in cents to be charged, represented as a whole integer. For example `9900` is equivalent to `$99`. If `ad_hoc=true` the `amount` is optional.

archived.description: Whether or not this price is archived.

currency.description: Three-letter ISO currency code, in lowercase. If not set, this value will fallback to the default `Account` currency.

description.description: The price's description, meant to be displayable to the customer.

name.description: The price's name, meant to be displayable to the customer.

recurring_interval.description: The frequency at which a subscription is billed. One of `week`, `month`, `year`, or `never`.

recurring_interval_count.description: The number of intervals (specified in the `recurring_interval` attribute) between subscription billings. For example, `recurring_interval=month` and `recurring_interval_count=3` bills every 3 months. The total duration of a billing cycle is not allowed to exceed 1 year.

tax_behavior.description: Specifies whether the price is considered inclusive of taxes or exclusive of taxes. One of `inclusive` or `exclusive`.

trial_duration_days.description: The default number of trial days when subscribing a customer to this price.

archived_at.description: Time at which the object was archived. Measured in seconds since the Unix epoch.

current_version.description: Whether or not this object represents the current version of this Price. (This will only be `false` if this `Price` is associated with a `LineItem` prior to it being changed. In this case we will lookup the version of the `Price` at the time it was associated.)

enabled.description: Whether or not this account has completed onboarding and is able to processs payments with this processor.

external_account_id.description: This account's external account ID with this processor. For example, this will be the Stripe account ID if the `processor_type` is `stripe`.

processor_type.description: The specific type of processor. The only allowed processor right now is `stripe`.

archived.description: Whether or not this product is archived.

description.description: The product’s description, meant to be displayable to the customer.

name.description: The product’s name, meant to be displayable to the customer.

recurring.description: Whether the product is for a one-time purchase or a recurring (subscription) purchase.

tax_category.description: The tax category/code that matches this product – one of `digital`, `tangible`, `service`, or `saas`.

tax_enabled.description: If set to `true` this product is considered taxable.

image_upload_id.description: The upload UUID that you want to attach to this product. This will replace the existing image, if one exists. If `purge_image` is also set to `true` the new image will not be attached.

product_group.description: The UUID of the product group.

purge_image.description: If set to `true` the product image will be removed.

archived_at.description: Time at which the object was archived. Measured in seconds since the Unix epoch.

image_url.description: The URL of the product image.

currency.description: The currency that was used to calculate these metrics. This will always be set to the account's currency.

max_price_amount.description: The maximum `amount` from this products not archived prices.

min_price_amount.description: The minimum `amount` from this products not archived prices.

prices_count.description: The total number of not archived prices that belong to this product.

archived.description: Whether or not this product group is archived.

name.description: The product group’s name, meant to be displayable to the customer.

archived_at.description: Time at which the object was archived. Measured in seconds since the Unix epoch.

archived.description: Whether or not this promotion is archived.

code.description: The customer-facing code. Regardless of case, this code must be unique across all promotion codes on your account. If left blank, we will generate one automatically.

expired.description: Whether or not this promotion has expired.

max_redemptions.description: Maximum number of times this coupon can be redeemed, in total, across all customers, before it is no longer valid.

redeem_by.description: Date after which the coupon can no longer be redeemed.

archived_at.description: Time at which the object was archived. Measured in seconds since the Unix epoch.

expired.description: Taking into account the above properties, whether this promotion can still be used.

live_mode.description: Set to `true` if this purchase is in live mode, and set to `false` if it is in test mode.

revoked.description: Whether or not this purchase is revoked.

revoked_at.description: Time at which the purchase was revoked. Measured in seconds since the Unix epoch.

invoice_item.description: The associated invoice item. (This will only exist for invoice items associated with one-time products.)

line_item.description: The associated line item. (This will only exist for line items associated with one-time products.)

amount.description: The amount in cents that was refunded, represented as a whole integer. For example `9900` is equivalent to `$99`.

reason.description: The reason for this refund, which can be one of `duplicate`, `fraudulent`, `requested_by_customer`, or `expired_uncaptured_charge`.

revoked_purchases.description: An array of UUIDs of the purchases that should be revoked when this refund succeeds.

currency.description: Three-letter ISO currency code, in lowercase.

external_refund_id.description: The external processor ID representing this refund.

live_mode.description: Set to `true` if this refund is in live mode, and set to `false` if it is in test mode.

revoked_purchases.description: The associated purchases that will be revoked when this refund succeeds.

status.description: The current status of this refund, which can be one of `pending`, `succeeded`, `failed`, or `canceled`.

object.description: A string describing the object type returned.

limit.description: The number of items per page. The default is `20` and the maximum is `100`.

deleted.description: Whether or not this object was succesfully deleted.

id.description: The UUID of the specific object.

object.description: A string describing the object type returned.

metadata.description: Set of key-value pairs that you can attach to an object. This can be useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured format.

created_at.description: Time at which the object was created. Measured in seconds since the Unix epoch.

updated_at.description: Time at which the object was last updated. Measured in seconds since the Unix epoch.

currency.description: Three-letter ISO currency code, in lowercase. If not set, this value will fallback to the default `Account` currency.

live_mode.description: Set to `true` if this subscription is in live mode, and set to `false` if it is in test mode.

trial_end_at.description: If the subscription has a trial, the end of that trial.

quantity.description: The quantity of products being purchased.

discount.description: The parameters of the discount to be applied to this subscription.

payment_method.description: The UUID of the payment method.

purge_pending_update.description: When set to `true` the `pending_update` will be cleared.

cancel_at_period_end.description: If the subscription is set to cancel at the end of the current period. You can use this attribute to determine whether a subscription that has a `status` of `active` is scheduled to be canceled at the end of the current period.

current_period_end_at.description: End of the current period that the subscription has been invoiced for. At the end of this period, a new invoice will be created. This will be `null` when the subscription has a price with `recurring_interval=never`.

current_period_start_at.description: Start of the current period that the subscription has been invoiced for.

price.description: The UUID of the price this subscription will be updated to at the end of the current period.

quantity.description: The quantity of products being purchased at the end of the current period.

ended_at.description: If the subscription has ended, the date the subscription ended.

status.description: The current status of this subscription, which can be one of `incomplete`, `trialing`, `active`, `past_due`, or `canceled`.

cancel_behavior.description: Controls how subscription cancellations should be handled – one of `immediate` or `pending`.

downgrade_behavior.description: Controls how subscription changes should be handled when downgrading – one of `immediate` or `pending`.

payment_retry_window_weeks.description: The number of weeks to retry failed subscription payments before canceling the subscription.

upgrade_behavior.description: Controls how subscription changes should be handled when upgrading – one of `immediate` or `pending`.

number_type.description: The type of tax ID number, one of `eu_vat` or `us_ein`.

ca_tax_enabled.description: If set to `true` GST taxes will be calculated for all Canadian provinces.

eu_micro_exemption_enabled.description: If set to `true` VAT taxes will be calculated using the account's home country VAT rate.

eu_tax_enabled.description: If set to `true` VAT taxes will be calculated for all EU countries.

tax_enabled.description: If set to `true` taxes will be automatically calculated.

ca_tax_identifier.description: The tax identifier to be used for all Canadian provinces.

eu_tax_identifier.description: The tax identifier to be used for all EU countries.

tax_identifier.description: The tax identifier to set for this tax registration.

tax_zone.description: The UUID of the tax zone.

average_rate.description: The average tax rate for state/province and local tax across all postal codes in the tax zone.

average_rate_label.description: The label used to describe the average tax rate.

minimum_rate.description: The state/province tax rate for the tax zone.

minimum_rate_label.description: The label used to describe the minimum tax rate.

headers.description: The headers to include when uploading the file to the hosting service.

url.description: The URL to use when uploading the file to the hosting service.

status.description: The current status of this upload which is either `pending` or `presigned`.

url.description: The public URL for accessing this file.

email.description: The email address of the user.

first_name.description: The first name of the user.

last_name.description: The last name of the user.

description.description: An optional description of what this webhook endpoint is used for.

enabled.description: Whether or not this webhook endpoint is active.

url.description: The URL of this webhook endpoint.

signing_secret.description: The webhook endpoint’s signing secret, used to generate webhook signatures.

tags.name: Abandonded Orders
tags.description: An abandonded order represents a customer's most recent incomplete order.

tags.name: Accounts
tags.description: This is an object representing a Presto Pay account. You can retrieve it to see properties on the account like it's current - name or default currency.

tags.name: Balance Transactions
tags.description: Each customer has a `balance_amount` value, which denotes a debit or credit that's automatically applied to their next invoice upon finalization. You may modify the value directly by creating a balance transaction, which increments or decrements the customer's balance by the specified amount.

tags.name: Brands
tags.description: A brand represents the design and branding settings for an account.

tags.name: Charges
tags.description: A Charge represents a credit or debit card transaction that was captured through one of your processors. Only succesfully captured charges are recorded in Presto Pay.

tags.name: Coupons
tags.description:
A coupon contains information about a percent-off or amount-off discount. 

The coupon object can be used to discount either one-time payments or subscriptions. There are some additional parameters that apply to subscriptions, but are not applicable to one-time payments, such as duration. Regardless of what duration is set to, it only applies once for one-time payments.

tags.name: Customers
tags.description: Customer objects allow you to perform recurring charges, and to track multiple charges, that are associated with the same customer. The API allows you to list and retrieve individual customers. Creating and updating customers is performed through Orders.

tags.name: Customer Links
tags.description:
Customer links are temporary "magic links" that allow access to customers through email lookup. They provide a secure way of granting access to a customer without having the customer ID.

Each customer link is valid for the greater of 1 hour after it's `created_at` time or 1 hour after it's `first_used_at` time. This means that if a customer link is not used within the first hour it expires. If a customer link is used within the first hour then it is valid for another hour starting from the time it was first used. So, a customer link that is used 30min after it's created will be valid for a total of 1hr 30min.

tags.name: Customer Notification Protocols
tags.description: A customer notification protocol represents the customer notification settings for an account.

tags.name: Events
tags.description: Events are our way of letting you know when something interesting happens in your account. When an interesting event occurs, we create a new `Event` object. For example, when a subscription updates, we create a `subscription.updated` event.

tags.name: Invoices
tags.description: Invoices are statements of amounts owed by a customer, and are either generated one-off, or generated periodically from a subscription.

tags.name: Orders
tags.description: An order represents a collection of one-time and/or subscription products that a customer intends to purchase.

tags.name: Payment Intents
tags.description: A payment intent represents the process of collecting a payment method from your customer.

tags.name: Payment Methods
tags.description: Payment method objects represent your customer's payment instruments.

tags.name: Prices
tags.description:
Prices define the unit cost, currency, and (optional) billing cycle for both recurring and one-time purchases of products. Products help you track inventory or provisioning, and prices help you track payment terms. Different physical goods or levels of service should be represented by products, and pricing options should be represented by prices. 

This approach lets you change prices without having to change your provisioning scheme. For example, you might have a single \"gold\" product that has prices for $10/month, $100/year, and €9 once.

tags.name: Processors
tags.description: A processor represents a connection to a third-party payment processor like Stripe.

tags.name: Product Groups
tags.description: A group of related products – used to configure which products a customer can switch between when updating a subscription.

tags.name: Products
tags.description: Products describe the specific goods or services you offer to your customers. For example, you might offer a Standard and Premium version of your goods or service; each version would be a separate Product. They can be used in conjunction with Prices to configure pricing and Subscriptions.

tags.name: Promotions
tags.description: A Promotion represents a customer-redeemable code for a coupon. It can be used to create multiple codes for a single coupon.

tags.name: Purchases
tags.description: A purchase represents a specific product that a customer has paid for (one-time products), or is currently paying for (recurring products via a subscription). The purchase model is a summary of all products that a customer current should have "access" to.

tags.name: Refunds
tags.description: Refund objects allow you to refund a charge that has previously been created but not yet refunded. Funds will be refunded to the credit or debit card that was originally charged.

tags.name: Subscriptions
tags.description: A Subscription represents a recurring schedule to charge a customer on one of your processors.

tags.name: Subscription Protocols
tags.description: A subscription protocol represents the subscription settings for an account.

tags.name: Tax Registrations
tags.description: A tax registration represents a tax zone that is enabled for an account. Taxes will not be calculated for orders within a tax zone unless a matching tax registration exists.

tags.name: Tax Protocols
tags.description: A tax protocol represents the tax settings for an account.

tags.name: Tax Zones
tags.description: A tax zone represents a geographic area (country and state combinations) that taxes can be calculated for.

tags.name: Uploads
tags.description: Uploads represent files that are hosted on our servers. Files are uploaded directly to the underlying hosting service. To learn more about how uploads work, please contact support.

tags.name: Webhook Endpoints
tags.description:
You can configure webhook endpoints via the API to be notified about events that happen in your Presto Pay account.

Most users configure webhooks from the dashboard, which provides a user interface for registering and testing your webhook endpoints.

get.description: Returns a list of your abandonded orders.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: A limit on the number of items to be returned, between 1 and 100.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page of items you want returned.

parameters.name: ids[]
parameters.description: Only return objects with the given IDs. To pass multiple IDs your query parameters should be formatted like `?ids[]=foo&ids[]=bar` which will be translated to `['foo', 'bar']` by the server.

parameters.name: customer_ids[]
parameters.description: Only return objects that belong to the given customers. To pass multiple IDs your query parameters should be formatted like `?customer_ids[]=foo&customer_ids[]=bar` which will be translated to `['foo', 'bar']` by the server.

parameters.name: status[]
parameters.description: Only return objects with the given status. To pass multiple statuses your query parameters should be formatted like `?status[]=foo&status[]=bar` which will be translated to `['foo', 'bar']` by the server.

parameters.description: If true, the server will check the associated payment processor to see if a status change has occured. This is only applicable when the order is in the `finalized` state. (This should be used when retrieving a order immediately after it has been paid through the processor. In this scenario, it's possible that you'll request the order before the server has received the webhook from the processor. Setting this pararmeter to `true` prevents this scenario.)

get.description: Retrieves details of a specific subscription.

parameters.name: update_behavior
parameters.description: The strategy to use when updating this subscription – one of `immediate` or `pending`. If no value is provided, the corresponding subscription protocol `downgrade_behavior` or `upgrade_behavior` will be be used.

parameters.name: skip_product_group_validation
parameters.description: When set to `true` you can update a subscription's price regardless of the product group it belongs to.

parameters.name: skip_proration
parameters.description: When set to `true` the next invoice generated during an immediate update will not be updated.

parameters.name: cancel_behavior
parameters.description: The strategy to use when canceling this subscription – one of `immediate` or `pending`. If no value is provided, the subscription protocol `cancel_behavior` will be be used.

x-topics.title: Authentication
x-topics.content:
The Presto Pay API uses API keys to authenticate requests. You can view and manage your API keys in your dashboard.

Your API keys carry many privileges, so be sure to keep them secure! Do not share your secret API keys in publicly accessible areas such as GitHub, client-side code, and so forth.

Authentication to the API is performed via bearer auth, use `-H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR-API-KEY"` to authenticate.

All API requests must be made over HTTPS. Calls made over plain HTTP will fail. API requests without authentication will also fail.

x-topics.title: Errors
x-topics.content:
Presto Pay uses conventional HTTP response codes to indicate the success or failure of an API request. In general: codes in the `2xx` range indicate success. Codes in the `4xx` range indicate an error that failed given the information provided (e.g., a required parameter was omitted, a charge failed, etc.). Codes in the `5xx` range indicate an error with Presto Pay's servers (these are rare).

# HTTP Status Code Summary

These are all of the status codes that the Presto Pay API will return.
- `200` OK - Everything worked as expected.
- `400` Bad Request - The request was unacceptable, often due to missing a required parameter.
- `401` Unauthorized - No valid API key provided.
- `404` Not Found - The requested resource doesn't exist.
- `422` Unprocessable Entity - The request failed validation or was not allowed for another reason.
- `500` Server Error - Something went wrong on Presto Pay's end.

# Error Responses

All error responses will be formatted like the example below, and they will have at least the following keys:
- `http_status` The HTTP status code – matching the HTTP response status.
- `type` The type of error – more specific than the `http_status`.
- `code` The unique code for the error – this should be used for translations.
- `message` The human readable error message.

```json
{
  "http_status": "unprocessable_entity",
  "type": "not_found",
  "code": "product.not_found",
  "message": "Unable to find product with id='e0e92d34-aed9-4bb8-9107-89309370c4b'",
  "validation_errors": {}
}
```

# Validation Errors

If an error is due to object validation a `validation_errors` key will also be set within the error response. The validation errors response will be formatted like the example below, and each validation error will have the following keys:
- `attribute` The attribute the validation error is associated with.
- `type` The type of validation error.
- `code` The unique code for the validation error – this should be used for translations.
- `options` Any options that apply to this error – these can be used for translation interpolation. (For example, a numerical validation error might have options for `min` and `max`.)
- `message` The human readable validation error message.

```json
{
  "type": "unprocessable_entity",
  "code": "product.invalid",
  "message": "Failed to save product",
  "validation_errors": [
    {
      "attribute": "name",
      "type": "blank",
      "code": "product.name.blank",
      "options": {},
      "message": "can't be blank"
    }
  ]
}
```

x-topics.title: Expanding Responses
x-topics.content:
Many objects allow you to request additional information as an expanded response by using the `expand` request parameter. This parameter is available on all API requests, and applies to the response of that request only. Responses can be expanded in two ways.

In many cases, an object contains the ID of a related object in its response properties. For example, a price has an associated product ID. Those objects can be expanded inline with the expand request parameter. ID fields that can be expanded into objects are noted in this documentation with the expandable label.

In some cases, such as a list of all prices for a product, there are available fields that are not included in responses by default. You can request these fields as an expanded response by using the expand request parameter. Fields that can be included in an expanded response are noted in this documentation with the expandable label.

You can expand recursively by specifying nested fields after a dot (.). For example, requesting `customer` and `customer.billing_address` on a order will expand the customer and the customer's billing_address.

You can use the expand param on any endpoint which returns expandable fields, including list, create, and update endpoints.

Expanding list requests are plural, but expanding objects within a list are singular. For example, if you wanted to retrieve a order's line items and each line item's price, you would pass `list_items` and `list_item.price` as expand parameters.

You can expand multiple objects at once by identifying multiple items in the expand array. Expansions have a maximum depth of two levels, and you can expand up to 10 objects.

x-topics.title: Metadata
x-topics.content:
Some updateable Presto Pay objects (i.e. `Order` and `Product`) have a metadata parameter. You can use this parameter to attach key-value data to these objects.

You can specify up to 50 keys, with key names up to 40 characters long and values up to 500 characters long.

Metadata is useful for storing additional, structured information on an object. Metadata is not used by Presto Pay and won't be seen by your users unless you choose to show it to them.

Do not store any sensitive information (bank account numbers, card details, etc.) as metadata.

x-topics.title: Live & Test Mode
x-topics.content: When creating `Invoice`, `Order`, `PaymentIntent`, and `Subscription` objects you can specify `live_mode`. If you set `live_mode=false` then all interactions with processors will be done in their respective live or sandbox modes. This allows you to create test charges, subscriptions, and run full checkout flows without charging real payment methods.

x-topics.title: Pagination
x-topics.content: Presto Pay utilizes offset-based pagination, and all top-level API resources have support for bulk fetches via "list" API methods. For instance, you can list products, prices, and customers. These list API methods share a common structure, taking at least these two parameters: `limit`, and `page`. The default pagination limit is `20` and the max is `100`.

x-topics.title: Webhooks
x-topics.content:
Presto Pay uses webhooks to notify your application when an event happens in your account. Webhooks are particularly useful for asynchronous events like when a subscription is updated or a charge is refunded.

You can create and manage your webhook endpoints through the API endpoints or within your dashboard. From your dashboard you can also see a log of recent events that have been sent.

# Events

Webhooks are triggered based on events. Events are our way of letting you know when something interesting happens in your account. When an interesting event occurs, we create a new `Event` object. For example, when a subscription is updated, we create a `subscription.updated` event.

The request payload of each webhook will contain the `Event` object, which is structured like the example below.

```json
{
  "id": "e1257591-bd43-4f27-9bc6-bac06c6191fb",
  "object": "event",
  "data": {
    "subscription": "2cca2a21-905c-4bc0-974d-bf67c37778e3"
  },
  "type": "subscription.updated",
  "created_at": 1632965090,
  "account": "26673c58-a5a7-47bf-bebb-0b00d2e9ebec"
}
```

# Types of Events

The following is a list of all the events that trigger webhooks:
- `purchase.created` – Occurs whenever a purchase is created.
- `purchase.invoked` – Occurs whenever a purchase is invoked. (This can only occur if the purchase has been previously revoked.)
- `purchase.revoked` – Occurs whenever a purchase is revoked.
- `purchase.updated` – Occurs whenever a purchase is updated. (This only occurs when a subscription's product or quantity changes.)

# Webhook Signatures

All webhooks include a signature in each request’s `x-webhook-signature` header. This allows you to verify that the events were sent by us, and not by a third party. We generate signatures using a hash-based message authentication code (HMAC) with SHA-256.

We generate a unique signing secret key for each endpoint.  If you use multiple endpoints, you must use the unique signing secret for each one you want to verify signatures on. You can view the signing secret for each endpoint from within your dashboard, or you can retrive it from the API.

# Preventing Replay Attacks

A replay attack is when an attacker intercepts a valid payload and its signature, then re-transmits them. To mitigate such attacks, we include a timestamp in the `x-webhook-timestamp` header. This timestamp is also part of the signed payload and verified by the signature, so an attacker cannot change the timestamp without invalidating the signature. If the signature is valid but the timestamp is too old, you can have your application reject the payload.

We generate the timestamp and signature each time we send an event to your endpoint. If we retry an event (for example, your endpoint previously replied with a non-2xx status code), then we generate a new signature and timestamp for the new delivery attempt.

# Verifying Signatures

**Step 1: Extract Signature and Timestamp**

The `signature` is sent in the `x-webhook-signature` header, and the `timestamp` is sent in the `x-webhook-timestamp` header.

```bash
x-webhook-signature = "287ace7f0267943970dca9e895be11a739b532b85dfed8a3d147ca2d08267f48"
x-webhook-timestamp = "1641873601"
```

**Step 2: Prepare Signed Payload String**

The `signed_payload` string is created by concatenating the `timestamp` and the `signature` with the `.` character. Using the above example values, the `signed_payload` would be `1641873601.287ace7f0267943970dca9e895be11a739b532b85dfed8a3d147ca2d08267f48`.

**Step 3: Determine Expected Signature**

Compute an HMAC with the SHA256 hash function. Use the endpoint’s signing secret as the key, and use the `signed_payload` string as the message.

**Step 4: Compare Signatures**

Compare the signature in the header to the expected signature.
